review_title: Mission-driven with thoughtful, caring leadership and hard-working team
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
CareMessage is truly mission-driven. It feels good to know that our hard work goes toward helping real people, and often the people most in need of help. Coming into work each day is easy when you know the impact you're having on real lives.

The team here is hard-working, thoughtful, and mature. We trust each other, and that shows in the support and thoughtfulness around the strong remote-work culture. The team is still relatively small and growing at the right pace, and we stretch ourselves to achieve big results.

I admire the senior leadership's care and concern they have for all aspects of the business, whether it is culture, employee happiness and growth, managing a healthy budget, or building the best product possible. We have already implemented solutions or are thinking ahead about the problems that arise as a company scales, and it's good to see the thoughtfulness there. The business itself is very healthy with good growth, strong customer retainment, and a solid balance sheet. We also have a supportive, experienced, compassionate Board of Directors.

For my own role, I have never felt quite as empowered, trusted, and supported, and I feel as if I'm relishing in that and growing all the time. We worked hard on ensuring a good alignment before I joined, and that has paid off in the time I've been here.

Practically speaking, the compensation is on the generous side of fair, the office benefits are satisfactory in the general tech world and excellent when looking at the broader job market (we are technically a non-profit, so are judicial with our funds), the work-life balance is healthy, the office is spacious and comfortable and in an amazing location.
cons:
I don't have many cons to say, so these are a bit of a reach, but I would note that the office can feel a bit quiet at times with several employees being remote-based and other folks being rather heads-down and focused on work, and perhaps slightly introverted. I do think this will continue changing as we hire more people and the energy livens up a bit. This may not be a "con" as it's easy to focus, but at times I do crave a bit more of a buzz and interpersonal engagement around the office — of course, we can all do our part to improve this, including me.

We have a few talent gaps in the team currently, but are working on filling them actively. This shows as a "con" in the meantime as some folks are spread a bit thin, but the company does recognize that and is working to address it.

Finally, we are technically a non-profit, which has certain limitations (e.g. there are no stock option incentives). This can be a con in some regards, but I feel that the salaries are strong enough to make up for that, and the company is truly run as a tech startup at its core, so you wouldn't really know we're a non-profit.

job_title: Non-Leadership Role in San Francisco, CA
pros:
CareMessage is laughable at best. The lack comes from the top down.  There is a lack of leadership, a lack of communication, and a lack of culture. This is just the beginning of where the lack begins. However, there is not a lack of ego, narcissism, and immaturity that blankets the culture of CM like a cheap blanket. The executive team consists of a clique of several bodies with one head.  It is this narrow, shared group thought that will be the ultimately be the downfall of CareMessage.  With that being said, everyone on the executive team knows their part and how to play the role. Do not say too much or disagree with the founder or co-founder. When the company knowledge is limited to a few key players there is no room for growth and development and eventual failure. 

The mission of CM is “CareMessage is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to empower healthcare organizations with mobile technologies to improve health outcomes and reduce the cost of care.”  CareMessage has prided itself on its mission and vision. CM uses this to pull on the heartstrings of its customers, donors, philanthropist, and employees. 

This mission is what has and continues to bring potential employees in for interviews.  As you begin to read this post, I want you to write down the “WHY” you want to work for CareMessage. The “WHY” is very important and can save you a lot of wasted time, energy, anger, frustration, disappointment, but most importantly your sanity and sense of self.  If you believe in the mission and the story CareMessage tells I understand why this may have you considering CM as a viable work option.  However, you may be one of the few (everyone else has left or been fired) who truly understand and believe in the mission including the founder and co-founder. If it is the warm and fuzzy pictures on Glassdoor do not be fooled. Be sure to ask in your interview how many of those people are still employees of CareMessage.  

If you are looking for a paycheck with an opportunity to learn what not to do come on board. In addition, you will receive no professional development, recognition, or opportunity to grow.  Sorry, those positions are already filled. 


Pros:
1.    Remote friendly. Although it can still be intrusive as people are not considerate and mindful of other people’s schedule, priorities, and time zones.  
2.    There are some smart and talented people at CM who actually believe in the mission even if they don’t understand the mission.
cons:
Cons:  What CM will not do:
1.    Respect or value employees 
2.    Reward/promote hard working staff with praises and raises
3.    Make sound decisions that aren’t personal
4.    Respect and appreciate experience and skills without being intimidated
5.    Provide a safe environment for employees to feel safe, secure, and heard

If these are things you can live with then, Welcome to CareMessage.

review_title: Toxic work environment caused by upper management and CEO
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Flexible work schedule
-Talented co-workers
-Many opportunities for learning
cons:
-True creativity, innovation and independence are not encouraged, appreciated or rewarded.
-Toxic work environment created by upper management and CEO, and nurtured by executive leads and managers.
-Culture of micromanagement and fear.
-Arrogant and inexperienced CEO and upper management. They are not open to feedback and fire or punish people who disagree with them or voice opinions contrary to theirs. Most managers and directors lack management experience and are sycophantic. Other people in senior executive positions who may be more experienced are there only because they don’t challenge upper management.
-In my experience, promotions aren’t based on past results and performance, but on how well you are liked by upper management (i.e., if you are their friend or don’t disagree with them.)
-Fluid staffing structure and changes are understandable given that CareMessage is a startup, but, when I was there, there was a high turnover rate that was not adequately addressed by executive leads or managers. This lead to way too frequent team restructuring, rushed organizational changes and low employee morale.
-Harsh firing practices and lack of transparency in hiring pipeline.
-Upper management tries to make up for toxic culture with perks such as snacks, catered food, and team events that almost nobody wants to go to. A good dose of acknowledgement and empathy will go a far longer way than all those perks combined.
-Lack of clear company vision due to zero leadership from CEO. When I was there, the direction of the company changed every quarter.
-In my opinion, the company has lost touch with its mission by heavily pushing for profits in an effort to become ‘self-sustained.’ 

For me, the flexible work arrangement and possibility of working remotely were by far the best things about working in CareMessage. The noble inspiration of working for a mission-driven company dissipated once I realized that people who are running the company are so arrogant and self-absorbed that they cannot truly embody the empathy required to help improve people’s health, which is a the core of the organization’s mission. This is such a shame because I truly enjoyed the work that I did there.

This disillusionment also carried through when I witnessed the leadership’s lack of empathy for employees. For the most part, employees are considered to be expenses rather than assets, and there is little concern for their well-being. If someone is liked (and by that I mean they are friendly with the bosses) they are rewarded and praised; if they aren’t liked for whatever reason, probably having nothing to do with work performance, they are disparaged and criticized. Experiencing any kind of satisfaction while working there, in my experience, is only an option when not speaking up against the broken culture and management style; not bringing up innovative ideas or making decisions within one’s scope that upper management doesn’t approve of first; and staying away from the mess as much as possible (if at all possible).
